title: "What is the Significance of the Legend of the Holy Grail and the 'Mystery' of the Empire?"
first_phrase: This final section discusses the legend of the Grail and the mystery of the empire, drawing on the recurring idea of a powerful "Lord of the World" in various traditions. It speaks to the concept of a mysterious and hidden realm, a sacred and immutable center that is represented as a land amidst the ocean of life, a solar land, or a place of light. Before this section, the text reflects on the concept of the universe and the convergence of universal justice and mercy towards our planet, the Center of the World, in which the seven heavens surround it. The passage also discusses the divine model on which our flesh is fashioned and the image of a truly divine face being seen in only a select few individuals. Additionally, it brings up the concept of every man being the double of a god, protected by the Kabbalah's Dragon of the Threshold, which dies and is reborn until it awakens as a god. (Based on "Le Symbolisme")
content: Chiuso come in un cerchio di ferro, la Kabbala ha dato un nome al suo guardiano: IL DRAGO DELLA SOGLIA. Corre qua e là e man- gia la polvere tutti i giorni, tutti i giorni! « Muore. Ma è per rinascere e morire e rinascere. Un giorno, prende coscienza di sé. Alla fine — poiché tutto ha una fine quaggiùalla fine, si sveglia dio ». (Da u Le Symbolisme ») III EA LA LEGGENDA DEL GRAAL E IL « MISTERO » DELL'IMPERO Nell'una o nell'altra forma, nelle tradizioni dei po- poli piú vari sempre ricorre l'idea di un possente « Si- gnore del Mondo », di un regno misterioso sovrastante ogni regno visibile, di una residenza avente, in senso superiore, il significato di un polo, di un'asse, di un centro immutabile, raffigurata come una terra ferma in mezzo all'oceano della vita, come una contrada sacra e intangibile, come una terra della luce, o terra solare. Significati metafisici, simboli e oscuri ricordi qui si intrecciano inseparabilmente.
last_phrase: In conclusion, the idea of a mystical and powerful ruler, the "Lord of the World," is a recurring theme in various traditions. Represented by symbols such as the stationary pole or the unchanging island, this idea is intertwined with metaphysical meanings and obscure memories. The concept of an unmovable ruler who governs through virtue is represented by various symbols, such as the cakravarti, a king of kings whose unstoppable power is like that of the wind. These notions are suggestive of a deeper understanding of our world and our place in it, inviting us to explore the mysteries that lie beyond our everyday experience.
